title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: There is no bridge over the Tweed near the Abbey, and we were rowed over in a skiff, which is the only mode of crossing the river.

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: As we stood, in silence, by that open vrindow, with the Tweed still rippling over its pebbly bed, it seemed hardly possible that thirty-six years had passed away since that most touching scene occurred, on that very spot.

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: "It was a beautiful day," says Lockhart, — "so warm that every window was wide open, and so perfectly still, that the sound of all others most delicious to his ear, the gentle ripple of the Tweed over its pebbles, was distinctly audible, as we knelt around his bed, and his eldest son kissed, and closed his eyes."

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: The drawing-room is a lovely apartment, with a large bay window looking out upon the Tweed, and the hills opposite.

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: "We found Abbotsford lying low on the banks of the Tweed, and hidden from the road by trees.

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: This pleasant village, picturesquely situated, as it is, on the Tweed, and at the base of the Eildon Hills, would have a charm in itself, but the elegant and graceful remains of its Abbey, so famous in romance and poetry, add greatly to its interest.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: In a moment more Mistress McWalter, a tall, masculine woman, with untidy hair of frosty blue-black, cametearing round the corner, while at the same time out ofthe back barn door issued John McWalter, armed with apitchfork, and followed by Tweed and Tyke, the clamourous shepherding dogs of Loch Spellanderie.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: John Me Walter had Tweedand Tyke with him, and they frisked their tails and gaveeach a little muffled bark to intimate that they shouldmuch like to join in the fray.
